overview: This subject is designed to provide students with detailed training in statistical methods as applied to the design and analysis of projects undertaken by postgraduate students, across all disciplines.
ilo: learn sound principles of design and research;
acquire skills in the analysis of research;
gain skills in the use of statistical software;
develop the ability to assess published research critically from a statistical point of view.

Prerequisites.content: This subject will involve mathematical, statistical and computing skills.

content.Name: Statistics
content.Teaching period: Summer Term (On Campus - Parkville)Semester 2 (On Campus - Parkville)

Non-allowed subjects.content: Students who have completed MAST10010 Data Analysis 1 or MAST10011 Experimental Design and Data Analysis must obtain subject coordinator’s approval before enrolling in this subject.

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Up to 8 online quizzes, including the use of statistical software (continuous assessment), equivalent to approximately 1000 words.

assessment.timing: At the conclusion of the subject

assessment.brief: An assignment on the analysis and interpretation of quantitative data from an empirical research study to be submitted two weeks after completion of the subject
assessment.timing: 2 Weeks after the end of teaching

date_times.contact_hours: 8 days intensive: 48 hours (24 hours of lectures and 24 hours of practical classes); 29 June to 3 July, and 13 July to 17 July.
